data.title: Election 2024: Semi-final results in for LA-area state Assembly races
data.meta_description: The top two vote-getters in the primary, regardless of party preference, will proceed to a November runoff. If there are only two candidates running, they will both automatically advance.
data.text:
Los Angeles County residents living in 24 state Assembly districts have cast their votes for who they want to represent them in Sacramento.

Early primary election results indicate slam dunks leads for several incumbents, while a few races are nail-biters and may not be settled for days or even weeks.

The top two vote-getters in the primary, regardless of party preference, will proceed to a November runoff. If there are only two candidates running, they will both automatically advance.

County Registrar-Recorder/County Clerk Dean Logan announced the semi-final results for Tuesday’s Presidential Primary Election early Wednesday. A total of 910,857 ballots were counted, with 16% of registered voters casting ballots. Many outstanding ballots remained to be counted, Logan said, but an official number was not announced. The first post-election day update is scheduled for later today, March 6.

Here’s where the races stand as of Wednesday morning:

See the latest election results.

Assembly District 34: Incumbent Republican Assemblymember Tom Lackey led the race to represent Barstow, Palmdale, Lancaster and Needles with 66.4% of the vote. Democratic challenger Ricardo Ortega, a peer advocate with the Children’s Law Center of California, followed with 33.6%.

Assembly District 39: Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Juan Carrillo led the race to represent Victorville and parts of Palmdale and Lancaster with 51.2% of the early vote. His Republican challenger Paul Marsh, a former Palmdale city councilmember, followed with 48.8% of the vote.

Assembly District 40: Republican challenger Patrick Gipson, former L.A. County sheriff deputy, snagged 54.3% of the vote, putting him in the lead to represent Santa Clarita and part of the San Fernando Valley. Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Pilar Schiavo had 45.7% of the vote,

Assembly District 41: With 41.9% of the vote, Republican former Altadena City Councilmember Michelle Del Rosario Martinez with 36.6% led the race to replace termed-out Democratic Assemblymember Chris Holden and represent Pasadena, Altadena, La Cañada Flintridge, Monrovia and Sierra Madre in L.A. County and Rancho Cucamonga, Wrightwood, San Antonio Heights in San Bernardino County. Democratic former mayor of Sierra Madre John Harabedianwas next with 30%. Following the top two were Democratic public safety executive Phlunte’ Riddle with 14.7% and Democratic Claremont City Councilmember Jed Leano with 13.3%.

Assembly District 42: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Jacqui Irwin snagged 53% of the vote, putting him in the lead to represent Calabasas, Simi Valley and Thousand Oaks. Republican challenger Ted Nordblum followed with 46% of the vote.

Assembly District 43: With 39% of the vote, Democratic Mayor of San Fernando Celeste Rodriguez led the race to fill the seat of former Democratic Assemblymember Luz Rivas, who is currently running for Congress. Rodriguez was followed by Republican San Fernando city commissioner Victoria Garcia with 27% of the vote, Democratic Attorney General Spokesperson Walter Garcia with 16%, Republican office administrator Felicia Novic with 8% and Democratic childcare provider Saul Hurtado with 4%. The district covers the northeastern San Fernando Valley from Sylmar to Van Nuys.

Assembly District 44: With 29.6% of the vote, Republican construction manager Tony Rodriguez led a crowded race to represent the Eastern San Fernando Valley and replace Democratic Assemblymember Laura Friedman who is currently running for Congress. Democratic Mayor of Burbank Nick Schultz was next with 24.7%. Following the leaders: Democratic UCLA law lecturer Ed Han with 15.7%, Democratic Glendale City Councilmember Elen Asatryan with 14.1%, Democratic progressive activist Steve Pierson with 6.9%, Democratic businesswoman Carmenita Helligar with 5.5%, entrepreneur Adam Summer with 2.3% and Democrat Adam Pryor with 1.2%.

Assembly District 46: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Jesse Gabriel led the race to represent the western San Fernando Valley with 60.8% of the vote. His Republican challenger, teacher Tracy Schroeder, followed with 39.2% of the vote.

Assembly District 48: Republican real estate business owner Dan Tran, with 43.6%, led the race to represent West Covina, Baldwin Park, Glendora, Covina, Azusa, Duarte and Monrovia. Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Blanca Rubio was second with 40.2% of the vote. Democratic Mayor of West Covina Mayor Brian Calderón Tabatabai was third with 16.2% of the vote.

Assembly District 49: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Mike Fong led the race to represent Alhambra, Arcadia, El Monte, Monterey Park, Rosemead, San Gabriel, San Marino, South Pasadena and Temple City with 60% of the vote. His Republican challenger attorney Long “David” Liu followed with 39.7%.

Assembly District 51: Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Rick Chavez Zbur had 74% of the vote, putting him in the lead to represent Hollywood, Franklin and Beachwood canyons, West Hollywood, Beverly Hills and Santa Monica. His two Republican challengers, entrepreneur Stephan Hohil and small business owner Shiva Bagheri followed with 13.4% and 12.6% respectively.

Assembly District 52: Democratic women’s rights advisor Jessica Caloza snared 29.62% of the vote, putting her in the lead to succeed Democratic Assemblymember Wendy Carillo, who is currently running for Los Angeles City Council, and represent East Los Angeles including the neighborhoods of Lincoln Heights, Highland Park, Glassell Park, Eagle Rock, Los Feliz, Silver Lake and Echo Park. She was followed by Democratic justice advocate Franky Carrillo with 19.8% of the vote, Republican nonprofit research assistant Stephen Sills with 16.8%, Democratic environmental policy advisor David Giron with 11.7%, Democratic housing advocate Ari Ruiz with 8.2%, Democratic community advocate Sofía Quiñones with 3%, Democratic public education advocate Genesis Coronado with 3.5%,Democratic restaurant owner Anthony Fanara with 1.5% and Green Party diversity committee co-chair Shannel Pittman with 1.6%.

Assembly District 53: Republican law enforcement educator Nick Wilson had 43.8% of the vote putting him in the lead to replace termed out Democratic Assemblymember Freddie Rodriguez and represent Pomona, Ontario, Chino, Upland and Montclair. He was followed by Democratic commissioner for the California Police Officer Standards and Training Commission Michelle Rodriguez with 20.8% of the vote, Democratic Pomona City Councilmember Robert Torres with 17.8%, Democratic Executive Director of the Inland Coalition for Immigrant Justice Javier Hernandez with 13.2% and Democratic education activist Carlos Goytia with 4.5%.

Assembly District 54: Democratic District Director for Assemblymember Santiago Mark Gonzalez had 45.1% of the vote putting him in the lead to replace termed out Democratic Assemblymember Miguel Santiago and represent Koreatown, Westlake, Chinatown, Little Tokyo, Boyle Heights, Vernon and Montebello. He was followed by Democratic nonprofit executive director John Yi with 31.6% and Republican medical health care recruiter Elaine Alaniz with 23.3%.

Assembly District 55: Democratic incumbent Rep. Isaac Bryan leads the race to represent Crenshaw, Culver City, Ladera Heights, Mar Vista, Del Rey, Palms, Pico-Robertson, Beverly Grove and Mid-Wilshire with 80.6% of the vote. His Republican challenger software developer Keith Cascio followed with 19.4% of the vote.

Assembly District 56: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Lisa Calderon led the race to represent the San Gabriel communities of El Monte, Hacienda Heights, La Habra Heights, La Puente, Pico Rivera and Whittier with 52.5% of the vote. Republican Whittier City Councilmember Jessica Martinez had 34.6% and Republican human resources administrator Natasha Serrano had 12.9%.

Assembly District 57: With 35.9% of the vote, small business owner Efren Martinez led the pack of five Democrats seeking to replace termed out Democratic Assemblymember Reggie Jones-Sawyer and represent South Central and Downtown Los Angeles. He was followed by educator Sade Elhawar with 27.7% of the vote, educator Dulce Vasquez with 14%, reparations advocate Tara Perry with 11.9% and educator Greg Akil with 10.5%.

Assembly District 61: Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Tina Simone McKinnor led the race to represent Inglewood, Westchester, Lennox, Hawthorne, Westmont and Lawndale with 76.1% of the vote. Her Republican challenger restaurateur Alfonso Hernandez had 23.9%.

Assembly District 62: In a tight showdown, Democratic Lynwood Mayor Jose Luis Solache led the race with 38.3%, aiming to replace termed out Democratic Assemblymember Anthony Rendon and represent Bellflower, Huntington Park, Lakewood, Lynwood, Maywood, Paramount, South Gate and Walnut Park. He was followed by Republican retired Marine Paul Jones with 38.2%, with just 21 votes separating the top two. Democratic community activist Maria Estrada with 23.4%.

Assembly District 64: With 54.5% of the vote, Democrat incumbent Assemblymember Blanca Pacheco led the race to represent Bell, Bell Gardens, Cudahy, Downey, East Whittier, La Mirada, Norwalk, Santa Fe Springs, South Whittier and La Habra. His Republican challenger minister Raul Ortiz Jr. followed with 45.5%.

Assembly District 65: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Mike Gipson ran unopposed for this district, which runs from the Port of Los Angeles up to Compton and also includes portions of Carson and Long Beach.

Assembly District 66: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Al Muratsuchi led the race to represent most of the South Bay with 55.5% of the vote. His Republican challenger small business owner George Barks followed with 44.5%.

Assembly District 67: With 49.9% of the vote, incumbent Democratic Assemblymember Sharon Quirk-Silva led the race to represent Orange County cities of Brea, Fullerton and Buena Park and Cerritos in L.A. County. She was followed by Republican retired entrepreneur Beth Culver with 42.9% and pastor Jacob Woo Ho Lee with 7.2%.

Assembly District 69: Democratic incumbent Assemblymember Josh Lowenthal led the race to represent Avalon, Carson, and Long Beach with 64.2% of the vote. His Republican challenger police officer Joshua Rodriguez followed with 35.8%.
